Well there were--but it apparently was, at the very least, badly reported. As Tom Paine commented: 
The book ascribed to Matthew says 'there was darkness over all the land from the sixth hour unto the ninth hour--that the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the bottom--that there was an earthquake--that the rocks rent--that the graves opened, that the bodies of many of the saints that slept arose and came out of their graves after the resurrection, and went into the holy city and appeared unto many.' Such is the account which this dashing writer of the book of Matthew gives, but in which he is not supported by the writers of the other books.
 
 It is an easy thing to tell a lie, but it is difficult to support the lie after it is told. The writer of the book of Matthew should have told us who the saints were that came to life again, and went into the city, and what became of them afterwards, and who it was that saw them; for he is not hardy enough to say that he saw them himself;--whether they came out naked, and all in natural buff, he-saints and she-saints, or whether they came full dressed, and where they got their dresses; whether they went to their former habitations, and reclaimed their wives, their husbands, and their property, and how they were received; whether they entered ejectments for the recovery of their possessions, or brought actions of crim. con. against the rival interlopers; whether they remained on earth, and followed their former occupation of preaching or working; or whether they died again, or went back to their graves alive, and buried themselves.
 
 Strange indeed, that an army of saints should retum to life, and nobody know who they were, nor who it was that saw them, and that not a word more should be said upon the subject, nor these saints have any thing to tell us! Had it been the prophets who (as we are told) had formerly prophesied of these things, they must have had a great deal to say. They could have told us everything, and we should have had posthumous prophecies, with notes and commentaries upon the first, a little better at least than we have now. Had it been Moses, and Aaron, and Joshua, and Samuel, and David, not an unconverted Jew had remained in all Jerusalem. Had it been John the Baptist, and the saints of the times then present, everybody would have known them, and they would have out-preached and out-famed all the other apostles. But, instead of this, these saints are made to pop up, like Jonah's gourd in the night, for no purpose at all but to wither in the morning.

 You might even be there by midnight. You have no guarantee of even another hour on this earth. And I promise you, you won't be talking your usual trash. It will be the burning sulphur and flames of the Pit of Hell itself that you will come to realize is your new home, forever.

 Select Sermons | Christian Classics Ethereal Library

 The essence of apetheism to me is living in the now, not worrying about what the future (including death) holds for me. I prefer the company of people who actually worry about how they conduct themselves and treat people in this present life than I do people who worry about what happens when they die. How can you say you don't know what happens at death? Have you never seen anything die? Poof! One minute you're here, the next you're not. The body rots and that's that.

 Yes, often 2 or 3 times a week. Sometimes 2 or 3 times a night on those wonderful summer night weekends. Things often get a bit sporting in the ghetto. I've held their hands, I've watched them take their last breaths, I've heard their last words, I've watched them pray to their gods, I've watched them curse their gods. None of this sheds any insight into what happens when you die. 
 
 
If you believe in the possibility of ghosts or, spirits living beyond death, you better start being a groupie for EZ... because if you believe ghosts exist, then so does his heaven and hell scenario.

 I never said I did believe in these things. You must know by now that I consider Easy's view of heaven and hell to be superstitious nonsense. That in no way justifies a claim of knowledge regarding what happens after I die. 
 
 
In all of the history of humans on Earth, there is not one solid piece of evidence to validate the existence of life after death. People 'believe; in it because it makes them feel good. That's all.

 It occurs to me that there is not one solid piece of evidence to deny the existence of life after death either. I'm not saying that I believe either way, because I don't know. How arrogant does one have to be to claim to have knowledge of something that they have absolutely no proof or evidence of? 
 
 Nobody who has ever been dead has come back and told us what it is like. I have never been dead. So yes, I can honestly say I don't know what happens, and I can honestly say I don't care. I am happy to concern myself with living.
Bennedict

The essence of apetheism to me is living in the now, not worrying about what the future (including death) holds for me. I prefer the company of people who actually worry about how they conduct themselves and treat people in this present life than I do people who worry about what happens when they die. I try to live my life accordingly. If you call that a waste of space...so be it.
 
 
 Yes, often 2 or 3 times a week. Sometimes 2 or 3 times a night on those wonderful summer night weekends. Things often get a bit sporting in the ghetto. I've held their hands, I've watched them take their last breaths, I've heard their last words, I've watched them pray to their gods, I've watched them curse their gods. None of this sheds any insight into what happens when you die. 
 
 
 I never said I did believe in these things. You must know by now that I consider Easy's view of heaven and hell to be superstitious nonsense. That in no way justifies a claim of knowledge regarding what happens after I die. 
 
 
 It occurs to me that there is not one solid piece of evidence to deny the existence of life after death either. I'm not saying that I believe either way, because I don't know. what is said in a particular religious scripture. genesis 1: you can either think "yea, i think that happened" or "nah, thats a load of rubbish." humans tend to make personal assessments when dealing with opinions, rather than saying "well, i dont know, im stumped."

 As for religious scripture, no, I don't believe any of it (christian, jewish, muslim, hindu, buiddhist, to be based in fact or reality. To me, they represent mans effort to understand that which we simply cannot understand. I think some of them have good ideas on how we as humans should live, but that's another subject. 
 
 
 when was the last time you fully knew about an opinion on a subject but didnt have one yourself?

 Just because I have an opinion on something does not mean that I am certain one way or another. I think man-made religion as we know it is nothing more than a sham that was originally thought of as a way of explaining things we don't understand, and has evolved into a way of controlling people. Does that discount the possiblity of a higher power...no. 
 
 
thats really the only case i can see as being truly agnostic, if you dont know the argument, which im pretty confident you do. very young kids are arguably agnostic. but then again, you could be thinking in the same way i am when i call everybody agnostics - there simply isnt enough evidence for anyone to make a conclusion, but again thats philosophy, not religion. religion deals with faith or lack of faith. either you have the faith bug or you dont.

 When I think of the possibility of a "god", I think of the universe. Where did it come from...a big bang? Ok, I'll buy the big bang theory...a singularity of energy floating around that exploded into what we today know as the universe (btw: I know that is a higly simplified version...just making a point). Where did that energy come from? What was the place that the singularity was floating around in? What made it happen? 
 
 These are questions that we as humans do not have answers to, and probably will never have answers to, but they do require that they be asked. So many "atheists" and "agnostics" seem content with the answer that "god" didn't create the universe, the big bang did. I am simply not satiated with this. There must be more out there than a big bang. Everything that we have, see, touch, and know in the entire universe had to have come from somewhere or something. A higher power...perhaps. Do I think it is some old man with a snowy white beard floating around watching us in the bathroom...no. 
 
 So where does the apetheist side come in? Just like this: am I curious about these questions?...sure, I think at some level everyone is. Do I care if they are ever answered in my lifetime...no. Do I think that any type of "afterlife" awaits me...no. 
 
 Do I know anything for certain? No.

 however, i am very happy to call myself an agnostic, along with everyone else when it comes to philosophy. youve shown the reasons for "philosophical agnosticism" (emoticon_xgood) which are very applicable, and exactly the reasons why everybody is a "philosophical agnostic".

 I think most atheists would would admit that we don't know what caused the Big Bang, and it is very possible that we may never know or that it can't be known. The point is that just because we don't know what caused it, doesn't mean we should believe that it was a god who caused it. 
 
 But I don't think the atheist/agnostic answer you are referring to is really trying to ignore the 'ultimate cause' of the Big Bang or anything, I think they are simply saying that the Big Bang was the cause of the universe as opposed to God just poofing everything into existence in the classical sense... I hope that made sense.
MrWriteLA

For me, it comes down to the idea that an intelligent, invisible, all-knowing, wildly self-contradictory being/designer constructed the universe (whether you define it as the Earth alone or as an incomprehensibly vast conglomeration of stars, planets, quasars, etc.) for whatever unknown reason... and is paying constant, all-knowing attention--also for unknown reasons--to the sex life of absolutely every organism on/within it, how much they're praising him at every given second, whether they're eating shellfish, spilling their seed, etc., etc.
 
 Which to one degree or another with irrelevant variations, all earthly "religions" ultimately boil down to.
 
 Which, as a basic concept, I find so mind-bogglingly, feeble-mindedly preposterous as to not even approach the minimum requirement for being a wildly remote "possibility"--much less a seriously-taken belief.
 
 Yeah, sure... it could be true... as much as, say, a three-year-old with Tourettes might babble during an epilectic fit, or the idea that we're a molecule in a fart emitted by a turtle owned by the leprechaun son of an inhabitant of an alternate existence.
 
 But none of the them are anything I can connect--even negatively--with terms like "atheism," "agnosticism" or even "philosophy."
 
 At least, not with a straight face.
